title: Holiday Movie Preview
text:
Crusading newspaper journalists (three cheers!) are the heroes in “Spotlight,” which is getting lots of Oscar buzz (Nov. 20). 
The big Thanksgiving Weekend film is Pixar’s “The Good Dinosaur.” 
And the buzz is good about Ron Howard’s “In the Heart of the Sea” (Dec. 11), about 19th Century whalers. 
Finally, on Christmas Day, Alejandro González Iñárritu follows up his Oscar-winner “Birdman” with the epic Western “The Revenant.” 
So, with those titles in mind, here’s Choices’ annual holiday-movie preview (Remember, release dates can change, so keep an eye on Choices throughout the holidays for updates): 
Friday 
•“Burnt” — Bradley Cooper plays a chef obsessed with getting his restaurant a prestigious Michelin star. 
• “Scouts Vs. Zombies” — A bunch of boy scouts team up with strippers to fight the zombie apocalypse. No, really. 
• “Our Brand is Crisis” — Sandra Bullock plays an American political campaign manager hired by a candidate for the presidency of Bolivia. Billy Bob Thornton co-stars. 
Nov. 6 
• “Spectre” — Daniel Craig is back as James Bond. Christoph Waltz is the bad guy. 
• “Room” — This drama about an abducted woman and her young child is getting a lot of Oscar buzz. 
Snoopy, Charlie Brown and the rest of the gang In “Peanuts.” (Photo: 20th Century Fox) 
• “Peanuts 3D” — Charles Schulz’s beloved comic page creations come to the big screen. 
Nov. 13 
Antonio Banderas stars in “The 33.” (Photo: Warner Bros.) 
• “The 33” — Based on the true story of 33 miners from Chile trapped underground. Antonio Banderas stars. 
• “By The Sea” — Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie star as a dysfunctional couple taking a vacation in France. 
• “Love the Coopers” — It’s dysfunctional family week! This one stars Diane Keaton trying to keep her family together over the holidays. 
• “My All American” — Based on the true story of Freddie Steinmark, an undersized college football star who comes down with cancer. 
Nov. 20 
• “Secret In Their Eyes” — An English-language version of the sprawling Oscar-winning Chilean murder mystery. It stars Julia Roberts, Nicole Kidman and Chiwetel Ejiofor. 
• “Spotlight” — Michael Keaton, Rachel McAdams, Mark Ruffalo and Liev Schreiber star in this based-on-true-story about the Boston Globe’s investigation of child sexual abuse in the Catholic Church. The movie is getting lots of Oscar buzz. 
Jennifer Lawrence stars in “Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2” (Photo: Lionsgate) 
•“Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2” — Jennifer Lawrence is back leading rebel forces against evil government forces. 
• “The Night Before” — Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Seth Rogen and Anthony Mackie star in this raunchy comedy about the holidays. Looks like a re-heated version of “Harold and Kumar.” 
Nov. 25 
•“The Good Dinosaur” — A young dinosaur develops an unlikely friendship with a boy in this Pixar fil m. 
•“Brooklyn” — A young Irish emigre (Saoirse Ronan) falls in love with an Italian-American boy in 1950s New York City. 
Sylvester Stallone and Michael B. Jordan star in “Creed.” (Photo: Warner Bros.) 
•“Creed”— Sylvester Stallone is back as Rocky, this time training the son (Michael B. Jordan) of his onetime foe Apollo Creed. 
•“Victor Frankenstein” — Daniel Radcliffe plays Igor to James McAvoy’s Dr. Frankenstein in this re-envisioned tale of Mary Shelley’s classic tale. 
Dec. 4 
• “Krampus” — No this isn’t a movie about feminine hygiene problems. It’s about evil supernatural forces terrorizing a dysfunctional family during the holidays. 
Dec. 11 
• “ In the Heart of the Sea” — Ron Howard’s movie purports to the story of the incidents that inspired the classic novel “Moby Dick.” 
•“Legend” — Tells the true story of infamous London gangsters the Krays, twins who terrorized 1950s and ’60s England. Tom Hardy stars. 
Dec. 18 
•“Sisters” — Tina Fey and Amy Poehler play middle-aged woman who decide to relive their teenage years by throwing one last wild party in their childhood home. 
“Star Wars: The Force Awakens” is set to be the biggest film of the holiday season. (Photo: Lucasfilm) 
•“Star Wars: The Force Awakens” — A sober Swedish-language film about the frailty of life. Just kidding! Luke, Han, Leia and Chewbacca are back in the most eagerly anticipated pop culture event of the year. 
Dec. 23 
•“Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Road Chip” — The rodents are back. Call an exterminator, quick! 
Christmas Day 
•“Concussion”— Will Smith plays the Nigerian-born doctor who discovers a brain disease caused by head trauma that plagues NFL players in this based-on-true-events movie. 
•“Daddy’s Home”— Will Ferrell plays the step-dad who competes with the layabout birth father Mark Wahlberg over the affection of the stepchildren. 
•“Point Break”— A remake of the 1980s surfers-turned-bank robbers. One question: Why?
